children.alt: Driven Only Eight Miles, This 1987 Buick GNX Is Basically New

children.text: Out of 547 produced for the single model year, this is the 480th production GNX, and it only has a handful of miles on the clock, which fetched it a healthy new valuation

As we look back on the biggest stories of 2019, the low-mileage 1987 Buick GNX with only eight miles on the clock sure caught the attention of our readers. It sold for a price that would go on to set trends at auction events throughout the year. If you're looking for a similar example,
through RK is a steal at $179K, and it's nearly the same scenario with 460 miles and the factory plastics still intact.
The GNX that cracked headlines in 2019

was sold by Ralph’s Buick in Mena, Arkansas in 1987 where it then went on to sit on display in a Texas showroom, and never driven. After sitting on display, and fending off any kind of driving time, unfavorable conditions, and keeping that clock low, the person who sold recently it had bought it in 2002 from the dealer’s showroom. From there, he moved it into a climate controlled showroom for storage. So in essence, this is likely the closest any of us will get to seeing a ‘brand new’ GNX, in 2019 - and that was worth an astonishing $200,000 to one bidder, who now gets to take the car home.

When sold new in 1987, this GNX carried an MSRP of just under $30K, so they weren’t super cheap for their time. In recent years, we’ve seen an assortment of low mileage examples top the $100K mark, including one with only 362  miles, sold through Barrett-Jackson four years back. So the valuation is definitely growing, especially as clean, low-mileage cars are becoming less and less common to find for sale.

children.alt: Driven Only Eight Miles, This 1987 Buick GNX Is Basically New

children.text: So what would $30K in 1987, and a now $200K get you in 2019 from the GNX? A whole lotta car, even in stock form. Clearly, what set this Buick apart was the powertrain. It left the factory with a turbocharged 3.8-liter V6. The Garrett T3 turbocharger, larger intercooler, and a low-restriction exhaust to produce a rumored 300 horsepower when new - staggering for the late 80s. With the Hydramatic 200-4R 4-speed transmission and larger oil cooler, the GNX is clocked at 12.7-seconds in quarter-mile, at 113.1 mph.

This stock beast still has the protective plastic over the gauges, and the only changes ever made (outside of fluids/routine maintenance) are a swapped battery and a relay switch, and both of the removed original items are included in the sale.
